description.narrative:
*Outcome 1 (DRC + BDI): Households, including at-risk groups, in targeted communities have increased food production or have increased income through off-farm activities
*Outcome 2 (DRC) Food consumption of household members, especially of pregnant/lactating women and young children, in targeted communities has improved.
*Outcome 3 (DRC + BDI): The efficiency and effectiveness of community governance systems have improved.
*Outcome 4 (DRC + BDI): Mutual acceptance, collaboration and security in the targeted communities have mproved, also across genders.

This intervention is directly an estimated population of 60.000 people, or 10,000 households, in 38 villages of 4 health areas, including the total population of the latter is to 77346 inhabitants, with a total of 12891 households. That is to say in our vision, we want to reach 75% of total households in these 4 health areas of the zone of health of Mutwanga.

Within the Great Lakes, ZOA will focus its programming on North Kivu, DRC (in particular the eastern part of Beni District, close to Uganda’s border) and in Burundi on the northern part of Cibitoke province (close to borders with DRC and Rwanda). ZOA and its partners will focus on a bottom up approach, facilitating and strengthening community processes to enhance protection mechanisms and promote human security including conflict prevention and resolution.
The four outcomes to which the ZOA interventions will contribute are closely linked to each other. Improved agricultural production should not only lead to improved access to food and income, it is also a prerequisite for an improved nutritional status for all household members, while improved community governance as well as improved mutual acceptance and collaboration will create the necessary stability and enabling environment for households to undertake individual and group actions towards improved food and livelihood security.
Incoming fund Protacted Crises Programme
Incoming fund Protacted Crises Programme
Beneficiary households are involved in agricultural value chain activities (DR Congo).
Percentage of households in the targeted villages enrolled in at least one of the value chains promoted by the project

comment.narrative: At the end of the project, 1576 producers, or 22.5%, integrated into the agricultural network; The percentage is still low compared to the 60% forecast because several producers are still hesitant because, in the past, in other projects, they have diverted their production but only sold a part of it. Producers, processors, traders of agricultural products, transporters hesitate to organize their links in order to avoid taxation of the State.

description.narrative: Percentage of producers in the target villages participating in one of the promoted value chains selling their agricultural produce

comment.narrative: Of the 22.5% under indicator 1.4.1 (1576 households participating in the agricultural sectors), 648 producers (41%) carried out the bundling. The gain thus obtained is 20 USD on average per household for 25Kgs of peanut per household with a total production sold of 16 Tons

description.narrative: Relevant actors capacitated to implement at least three key issues of the two value chain development plans (development of one full value chain and contribution to the development of a second) over the 2.5 years of the programme

comment.narrative: 28 groups to work together: Some agricultural households and supported in income-generating activities were grouped together to 28 groups to work together and to develop micro-business plan of group.

description.narrative: Farmers have a better understanding of improved farming techniques (DR Congo)
Percentage of individual farmers in the target area knowing (at least four) improved agricultural methods promoted by the project has increased from x% by mid-2014 till y% by the end of 2016

comment.narrative: The improved techniques promoted by the project are: Setting fallow land, combining crops, crop rotation, composting, seed selection and selection, and crop maintenance. For the breeding the techniques learned are: the hygiene of the habitat of the animal, the feeding and the control of the reproduction.

description.narrative: Farmers have better access to agricultural inputs and improved agricultural infrastructure

Percentage of farmers in the targeted communities that have access to a minimum kit of agricultural tools (hoes and machetes) and seeds during the planting season has increased from x% by mid-2014 till y% by the end of 2016 (DR Congo)

comment.narrative: Each farm household received 2 hoes and seeds (10 Kg for beans, 10 for peanuts, 10 for rice, 50 grams for market gardeners including cabbages and aubergines); Each rabbit-breeding household was entitled to 3 rabbits including 1 male and 2 females; For the breeders of the Cobayes it was 4 females for a male. Thus, directly the project assisted 9000 households for the outcome 1 (6989 agricultural households and 2011 households breeders); We can add the households that received the seeds and broodstocks of the reimbursed rotating credits, which are 1042 households in total (779 agricultural households and 263 households). If we add that to our 9000 beneficiaries we have a total of 10042; If we compare them to the 16098 total households we find 62% of households that have access to a minimum agricultural kit and improved seed.

description.narrative: Households, including at-risk groups, in targeted communities have increased food production or have increased income through off-farm activities
At household level, annual yield of targeted crops (Haricots, Arachide, Rice) have increased from x kg by mid-2014 to y kg by the end of 2016 (DR Congo & Burundi)

comment.narrative: Haricot: 87,2 Kgs Arachide: 90Kgs Riz: 173Kgs Pour une superficie moyenne de 0,08 Ha

Haricot: 120 Kgs, Arachide: 132 Kgs, Riz: 185 Kgs. There was a slight decline in bean production compared to the past year following an extreme dry season in the eastern part of our intervention zone. At the end of the project, average overall production for the three main agricultural crops grown in the project increased by an average of 30.3%. 37.6% increase in beans; 46.6% for groundnuts but only 6.9% for rice. Rainfall is the limiting factor for rice production since there is no potential for irrigation.

description.narrative: Percentage of households in the target area involved in at least one livelihood strategy (IGA) promoted by the project that contributes to their income has increased from x% by mid-2014 to y% by the end of 2016 (DR Congo)

comment.narrative: In particular, agriculture, processing of certain agricultural products, bundling, income-generating activities, market gardening and the introduction of agribusiness within households in the region. The latter no longer depend only on agriculture but households have added other activities to have different sources of income.

description.narrative: Percentage of farmers, fishermen, cattle keepers and small traders indicating an increase in the financial benefits of their livelihoods activity. (disaggregated by gender and livelihoods activity) has increased from x% by mid-2014 to y% by the end of 2016 (DR Congo & Burundi)

comment.narrative: By disaggregating this population according to gender and the types of activities contributing to household income, we achieve the following results: Agriculture comes first with 40.3% of women against 25.4% of male farmers; Then the breeding 9.7% of the women against 6.7% of male breeders; And finally small business 17% of women against 0.3% of men small traders. Households reported that they had increased their incomes through trades. They manage to sell their production to people passing by as well as in neighboring Uganda.

description.narrative: Number of female head of households and victims/survivors of SGBV able to secure their livelihoods by engaging in a sustainable economic activity (DR Congo)

comment.narrative: Number of female head of households and victims/survivors of SGBV who are attended by the project: These women are either deprived widows (51%), early mothers (22%) and abandoned by the men who have cared for them and who take care of their own expenses, as well as separated mothers (27%).

description.narrative: Non agricultural households improved their entrepreneurial skills in business (DR Congo)
Annual number of non-farm households capacitated to diversify their activities during the year

comment.narrative: After identifying the trades chosen, a teacher was placed at their disposal to strengthen their capacities in the production, the sale as well as the calculation of the profitability. The courses are: embroidery, pastry, soap making, weaving baskets and weaving mat. After the training a Kit was made available to each household to start up their business.

description.narrative: Number of VSLA groups with 1 or more members of a non-agricultural household’ capacitated and supported to function in agreement with standards by the end of every year.

comment.narrative: The VSLA implementation activity was well accepted and appreciated by community members; The project has implemented 300 VSLAs but these VSLAs have generated up to the end of the project 32 other VSLAs
